channel.title: packages.debian.org APT package repository web interface for deb.whonix.org
channel.description:
Maybe we can somewhat easily prettify `deb.whonix.org`. Making information for packages by Whonix and later Kicksecure (on own domain name `kicksecure.com`) much more accessible. Could better present what packages exist, what the dependencies are, version numbers, which repository has which version, changelogs and whatnot. Would be much better searchable since it would get indexed by search engines.
This is apparently what `packages.debian.org` is using:
https://packages.debian.org/about/
https://salsa.debian.org/webmaster-team/packages
But looks rather involved to setup.
https://salsa.debian.org/webmaster-team/packages/-/blob/master/INSTALL
I would like to avoid re-introducing apache on `whonix.org`.
Is there any more lightweight alternative?

item.title: packages.debian.org APT package repository web interface for deb.whonix.org
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Documentation for this is very spare. If anyone could contribute how to set this up with nginx that would help a ton in getting this done.

Read full topic

item.title: packages.debian.org APT package repository web interface for deb.whonix.org
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
BunsenLabs have a pure-JavaScript based package index:

bunsenlabs.org

BunsenLabs Linux :: Repository index

BunsenLabs package list and search

github.com

BunsenLabs/bl-repo-index

OBSOLETE – See https://github.com/BunsenLabs/bunsen-website-nodev/blob/master/src/js/bl-repo-index.js instead

item.title: packages.debian.org APT package repository web interface for deb.whonix.org
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Patrick:

https://pkginfo.devuan.org looks decent. Haven’t found source code and installation instructions yet.

Patrick:

package information tracker similar to packages.debian.org?

Not sure if it is correct, but #devuan on freenode mentioned these git repos:

http://5.196.69.93/?q=d1pkg

–
bye,
pabs

http://5.196.69.93/d1pkgweb/

http://5.196.69.93/d1pkgweb-query/

mpi

Maemo Package Indexer

Current instance is running at: https://maedevu.maemo.org/pkgweb/

Fork of KatolaZ’s d1pkgweb tailored for Maemo Leste.

GitHub

maemo-leste/mpi

Maemo Package Indexer (fork of d1pkgweb). Contribute to maemo-leste/mpi development by creating an account on GitHub.

Read full topic

item.title: packages.debian.org APT package repository web interface for deb.whonix.org
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
https://pkg.kali.org/pkg/cifs-utils based on https://salsa.debian.org/qa/distro-tracker. Similar:
https://tracker.debian.org/pkg/apt. But not too great since it does not show package descriptions. Perhaps that is configurable? I haven’t found installation or configuration instructions yet.

https://pkginfo.devuan.org looks decent. Haven’t found source code and installation instructions yet.

Read full topic
item.source: packages.debian.org APT package repository web interface for deb.whonix.org

item.title: packages.debian.org APT package repository web interface for deb.whonix.org
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Maybe we can somewhat easily prettify deb.whonix.org. Making information for packages by Whonix and later Kicksecure (on own domain name kicksecure.com) much more accessible. Could better present what packages exist, what the dependencies are, version numbers, which repository has which version, changelogs and whatnot. Would be much better searchable since it would get indexed by search engines.

This is apparently what packages.debian.org is using:

packages.debian.org

Debian -- Debian Packages - About this site

GitLab

Debian Webmaster Team / packages

Packages website code. Repository imported from https://anonscm.debian.org/git/webwml/packages.git/

But looks rather involved to setup.

GitLab

INSTALL · master · Debian Webmaster Team / packages

Packages website code. Repository imported from https://anonscm.debian.org/git/webwml/packages.git/

I would like to avoid re-introducing apache on whonix.org.

Is there any more lightweight alternative?
